awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Gas Analyzers to Strengthen Multidisciplinary Research and Education at Tennessee State University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Tennessee State University (TSU) to acquire a state-of-the-art portable photosynthesis system and soil gas analyzer that will enhance multidisciplinary research and student training at TSU, a Historically Black College and University. The new equipment will be integrated into the curriculum at both undergraduate and graduate levels to enrich the research training and learning. The acquisition of the instrument will increase the ability of the faculty to attract and mentor under-represented minority students in the fields of ecology, agriculture, and environmental sciences, provide hands-on research experience to students conducting independent research projects, and prepare a diverse and competent workforce. The project will also help improve agricultural practices to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect the environment. 

Photosynthetic carbon fixation by plants plays a vital role for plant growth and crop yield while the releases of greenhouse gases from soils significantly influence global climate and environment. The equipment of photosynthesis system and greenhouse gas analyzer acquired will support research and teaching to address research questions in the areas of plant ecology, ecosystem ecology, crop molecular genetics and breeding, organic agriculture, and biogeochemistry. Specifically, the instrument will be used to investigate plant responses to drought and wet conditions, soil greenhouse gas emissions in grasslands and croplands, organic farming practices on crop physiology and production, and biochar and nitrogen applications on bioenergy crop and other crops? growth, yield, and soil greenhouse gas emissions. The acquisition of instrumentation will allow faculty and students to carry out the important research projects that would otherwise be significantly impeded at TSU. The requested instrument will greatly improve the research infrastructure for ecology, agriculture and environmental science research, enhance the faculty research capability, and improve their research productivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project are to improve the research and teaching infrastructure in the areas of ecology and environmental sciences at Tennessee State University (TSU), and to promote multidisciplinary research collaborations among different departments at TSU, with acquisition of two gas analyzers. The specific objectives include 1) to purchase two gas analyzers including Li-6800 Photosynthesis and Fluorescence System and Picarro G2508 Multiple Gases (CO2, CH4, N2O, NH3, H2O) Analyzer and Eosense Multiplexer with six smart automatic chambers; and 2) to use these instruments in student training and research projects to provide hands-on research experience, and improve research infrastructure for ecology, agricultural and environmental sciences research at TSU.

Intellectual Merit: With the support of this grant, we purchase the Li-6800, Picarro G2508 and Eosense soil chambers, plus an Li-7820 N2O analyzer, and used these instruments in student training and research projects. Specifically, 1) we provided training to faculty, graduate and undergraduate students on the use of the instruments. Graduate students and undergraduate learned how to use the instruments for data collection. Some data collected with the instrument have been used in classes taught by the PI and co-PIs. More than 250 undergraduate students have been directly benefited from the instruments; 2) the instruments have been used in several research projects funded by the NSF and USDA. For example, leaf photosynthesis of switchgrass under different warming, precipitation, and nitrogen application treatments have been measured in the field experiments at TSU Agricultural Education and Research Center. Students have gained hands-on research experience using these instruments. Some results generated by the instruments have been presented at the scientific meetings including AGU and ESA annual meetings. 3) This project also helped improve the research resources and facilities in ecology and environmental sciences at TSU. The PI and co-PIs have secured new grants from federal funding agencies such as NSF and USDA and provided more research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at TSU.

Broader Impacts:  The acquisition of these instrument significantly improved the resources and research infrastructure at TSU, a historically black college and university (HBCU). The project provided better training to students, particularly these minority students who are still underrepresented in ecology and environmental sciences. Both graduate and undergraduate students used these instrument gained valuable knowledge and improved their research skills and interests in natural sciences. Research findings were also disseminated through formal publications and presentations at scientific meetings. Overall, this project helped strengthen the education and research capability at TSU and build a more diverse workforce in ecology and environmental sciences.

Disclaimer

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Dafeng Hui
